title: Metabolic Effects of Fructose with Rick Johnson, M.D. | Part I
content: In this episode, Rick Johnson, professor of nephrology at the University of Colorado, explains how his research into the causes of blood pressure resulted in a change of research direction to focus more on how fructose has such profound metabolic effects. Rick begins by talking about the relationship between salt and high blood pressure, then provides a masterclass into uric acid, and then expertly reveals the mechanisms and pathways by which sugar (specifically fructose) can profoundly impact metabolic health. From there, he explains how he applies this information to real life patients as well as touches on some of the most promising ideas around pharmacotherapy that are being developed in response to the epidemics of fatty liver, insulin resistance, diabetes, and obesity. Furthermore, Rick gives his take on artificial sweeteners compared to real sugar, discusses cancer’s affinity for fructose, and much more.

title: How Fructose Drives Metabolic Disease with Rick Johnson, M.D. | Part II
content: In this episode, Rick Johnson, professor of nephrology at the University of Colorado, continues his discussion on the metabolic effects of fructose. He explains how fructose can lead to the development of fatty liver disease, insulin resistance, and type 2 diabetes. Rick also discusses the role of the gut microbiome in fructose metabolism and how it can contribute to metabolic disease. Additionally, he talks about the potential benefits of a low-fructose diet and the importance of reducing fructose intake in the prevention and treatment of metabolic disease.

title: The Physiology of Stress Response
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the widespread impact of stress on our physical and emotional health as well as the mechanisms by which it can precipitate chronic illness, dementia, depression, and more. He also provides insight into the factors that contribute to the stress response (and our ability to handle it) such as social rank, personality, environment, and genetics.

title: The Impact of Stress on Health
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the impact of stress on atherosclerosis, dementia, addiction, and depression. He also talks about the role of stress in cancer and how it can lead to chronic illness.

title: Tips for Managing Stress
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., provides tips for managing stress in the modern world. He talks about the impact of subjective socioeconomic status and social media on stress levels and health.

title: The connection between fructose and high blood pressure
content: Rick discovered that raising uric acid in animals led to high blood pressure, and sugar, particularly fructose, raised uric acid. They changed their research direction to focus on fructose's metabolic effects.

title: The relationship between salt and blood pressure
content: The prevailing thought is that too much salt elevates blood pressure, but it's actually the salt concentration that makes a difference. Drinking water with a salty meal can prevent a rise in blood pressure. Rick's 2018 study showed this. High blood pressure increases the risk for heart failure and stroke.

title: The cause of primary hypertension
content: Inflammation in the kidney due to an autoimmune reaction to heat shock proteins can lead to high blood pressure. The inflammatory response injures the kidney ischemically, leading to aberrant retention of sodium. This mechanism probably has a big role in the cause of primary hypertension.

title: The role of inflammation and sugar in hypertension
content: The discovery that inflammation in the kidney can be a mechanism for triggering persistent elevations in blood pressure and probably has a big role in the cause of primary hypertension. In the process of developing high blood pressure there are 2 players: initiators and things that make it persistent. The inflammation in the kidney is involved in the persistence. In the initiation, turns out that sugar has a major role. Rick’s 2013 study showed that when you give a high salt diet to animals…It increases the serum sodium which then activates an enzyme that converts glucose to fructose. This fructose is made in the body, not coming from the diet. The fructose then gets metabolized and raises blood pressure. In animals, when you block the metabolism of fructose, you actually block the rise in blood pressure.

title: Defining fructose, glucose, and sugar
content: Glucose is the primary sugar that our body uses to make energy. When that’s too high we call it diabetes. When the blood glucose is too low, it’s hypoglycemia. It can be stored in the tissues as glycogen. Fructose is a natural sugar found in fruit. Fructose is the sugar that is involved in energy storage rather than energy production. When you eat glucose, you use that to produce energy…but when you eat fructose, it will actually trigger changes in the body that will favor the storage of energy. This is the sugar that animals use to store energy. Fructose tastes a lot sweeter than glucose. Table sugar (aka sucrose) = glucose + fructose at 50/50 ratio. High fructose corn syrup = typically 55% fructose, 45% glucose in soft drinks.

title: An ancient mutation in apes that explains why humans turn fructose into fat so easily
content: The proconsul primates lived in Africa ~22 million years ago. They are part of the homosapien lineage. They ate primarily fruit. About 17 million years ago, there was a change in a global cooling that created a land bridge that allowed many of these apes to migrate from Africa to Europe. A few million years later, global cooling made it too cold in Europe to have year round fruit. And many of them starved to death. However, a small subset of them developed a mutation in uric acid metabolism that gave them a superpower. That superpower was that they could be much more efficient at turning fructose into fat. They had this little by-product which they would also make a boatload of uric acid along the way. Those apes with that mutation returned to Africa and ultimately seeded the rest of the species. Ultimately, that’s why we as humans are among the very rare animals that have uric acid levels that are quite high relative to other animals (cats and dogs, for example).

title: Uric acid and gout
content: The classic story told is that human’s get gout because of too much uric acid. And we increase our uric acid by eating too much meat and protein. The way you get gout from protein is from the DNA and RNA in the protein. Beer, for example, has brewer’s yeast and that is filled with RNA and so that’s why beer can precipitate gout.

title: Uric acid levels in men vs. women
content: Men have higher levels of uric acid, generally. Estrogen helps keep uric acid levels down (so after menopause, uric acid levels go up). Also, men may eat more meat.

title: Sugar and gout
content: Gout is also increased by sugar. The reason is because of the fructose content and when the fructose is metabolized, it generates uric acid. In the 1800s, the wealthier populations were drinking beverages sweetened with sugar.

title: Uric acid and high blood pressure
content: Peter credits Rick for making him aware that uric acid can lead to high blood pressure. Originally, they were studying what causes high blood pressure and some epidemiologic studies linked uric acid with high blood pressure. Rick then did a study in rats and gave rats uricase inhibitor to raise the uric acid of an animal, and the animals developed high blood pressure. Then, Rick could lower their blood pressure by lowering their uric acid. Rick then started putting soluble uric acid on cells and saw that it was causing pro-inflammatory effects.

title: Sugar and high blood pressure
content: Rick began to think “if fructose/sugar raises uric acid, maybe sugar could have a role in blood pressure.” Next, Rick did another experiment where he gave rats fructose and the animals developed high blood pressure. They then gave them allopurinol (a drug to lower uric acid by blocking its formation) and it made their blood pressure go back to normal. Even more exciting was these animals also developed insulin resistance, elevated triglycerides in their blood, and fatty liver. And when they lowered uric acid, there were benefits in all of those parameters.

title: Fructose vs. Glucose Metabolism
content: Fructose metabolism is different from glucose metabolism. When fructose is metabolized, there’s a process that causes the energy in the cell to fall before it goes up. Fructose is the only nutrient that lowers energy in the cell. The process of breaking down and metabolizing food or glucose or fructose requires spending a little bit of ATP before you make it more of it. When metabolizing glucose, the body has a system whereby it feeds back to stop the process before any significant ATP depletion occurs. But when fructose is metabolized, the enzyme that metabolizes fructose is called fructokinase, and when that metabolizes fructose, it consumes ATP in an unregulated way. So if the cell sees a lot of fructose, the ATP levels can plummet by 40 or 50% in the cell. And that produces a “May Day” signal, “we’re under attack, we’re running out of energy!”

title: Fructose and Weight Regulation
content: Fructose turns out to be used by animals as a mechanism to store fat. Normally animals will regulate their weight beautifully. But when it wants to gain fat, it will do so usually through a mechanism that involves fructose. A hibernating animal or a migrating bird, for example, will start eating a lot of fruit in to increase its weight. It gets hungry, it drops its metabolism so that most of the energy it eats goes into fat. And so this is a very common pattern and it’s driven by that ATP depletion.

title: Fructose and Uric Acid
content: Fructose causes a depletion of ATP, which triggers a series of reactions. The key reaction is that intracellular phosphate also falls, and that activates an enzyme called AMP deaminase (AMPD) that takes the broken down product of ATP (which is AMP) and it converts it to uric acid. And that process has multiple steps, and those steps are involved with the generation of increase in body fat, insulin resistance, fatty liver, and elevations in blood pressure. And that pathway is what seems to be critical for inducing obesity from sugar.

title: AMPK and AMPD Pathways
content: There are two pathways that can be taken: AMPK or AMPD. The AMPK pathway burns energy and fat, while the AMPD pathway stores energy. Stimulating AMPD can cause insulin resistance and eventually diabetes, while stimulating AMPK can be used to treat diabetes. The switch to tell which pathway to go is driven by intracellular phosphate. Fructose can cause the switch towards AMPD by sequestering phosphate. Interrupting the AMPD pathway can block many metabolic effects.

title: Drinking Sugar vs Eating Sugar
content: Drinking sugar is much more likely to cause obesity than eating sugar because we tend to drink a lot in a short period of time. When fructose gets to the liver, it's the concentration that triggers the reaction. The rapidness of absorption is what matters. Drinking a sugary soda on an empty stomach will be absorbed faster and trigger the AMPD pathway. Slowly eating a high protein meal with the same amount of sugar may not trigger AMPD.

title: Fructose and Metabolic Syndrome
content: Fructose can cause all five signs of metabolic syndrome: elevated blood sugar, elevated blood pressure, elevated waist circumference, elevated triglycerides, and low HDL. Fructose generates uric acid and lactate, decreases mitochondrial function, and stimulates glycolysis, causing oxidative stress to the mitochondria. Oxidative stress inhibits enoyl-CoA hydratase, blocking fat burning, and increases citrate, driving fat generation. Mitochondrial oxidative stress is linked with the development of insulin resistance. Uric acid also causes oxidative stress to the pancreatic islets.

title: Effects of high sugar intake on rats
content: Both groups maintained their weight. However, the high sugar rats developed fatty liver, hypertension, insulin resistance, and diabetes. The high sugar rats got 20% of their calories from fructose.

title: Sugar causing diabetes
content: They first became insulin resistant with high serum insulin levels (what we see in early type 2 diabetes patients). Over time, the rats serum insulin levels began to fall, resembling type 1 diabetes. There was low grade inflammation in the pancreatic islets and it was associated with big time upregulation of uric transport proteins on the islet. When we put uric acid on the islets, it induced oxidative stress and over time caused a drop in insulin level.

title: Fructose and cancer
content: For cancer cells… fructose can be an incredible survival nutrient in the setting of near starvation. Many cancers (colon, liver, kidney, breast, brain, all these cancer cells, intestinal) tend to like fructose as their preferential fuel. If you block fructokinase, many cancers don’t do as well.

title: Fructose and lactate
content: Fructose can be used by many areas of the body, including the liver, intestine, kidneys, brain, islets, adipose tissue, and skeletal muscle. The heart can even create fructose when needed. There is evidence that fructokinase is in the brain and that the brain can make fructose. Insulin resistance can occur in the brain, which might be an explanation for the development of Alzheimer’s disease. There are reports that AMP deaminase is high in the brains of Alzheimer’s patients.

title: Fructokinase inhibitors—a potential blockbuster?
content: Fructokinase inhibitors are being developed by Pfizer and were successful at treating fatty liver. They are now being taken to phase three. Fructokinase was an evolutionary thing that allowed us to survive long periods without food. In the Western world where we have an abundance of food, it’s really not necessary. Living without fructokinase would probably solve a lot of the world’s health problems.

title: Treating high uric acid levels—Rick’s approach with patients
content: Rick lowers uric acid levels in patients with high uric acid levels, typically with allopurinol. Some people get severe rashes from allopurinol. About 3% to 4% of Asians, about 2% in African Americans, and about 0.5% in Caucasians. Reasons other than gout to lower uric acid include improving insulin sensitivity, benefiting kidney disease, and improving blood pressure. Risks start to go up when the serum uric acid is over 5.5 for prediabetes, insulin resistance, hypertension, kidney disease, etc. Rick will always treat it if the level is 8 or higher. If it’s between 5.5 and 8, he generally has the discussion with the patient about the pros and cons of treatment.

title: Alternative to allopurinol?
content: Febuxostat probably works just as good as allopurinol, says Rick. But some people are concerned about an increased risk of cardiovascular mortality after the CARES trial when compared to allopurinol. But the problem with that study was that there was no placebo group. Plus Febuxostat is more expensive than allopurinol.

title: Salt intake
content: Salt and blood pressure: In general, salt does play a role in blood pressure. However, it’s NOT just about the total amount of salt. It’s the combination of salt and water. You want to avoid an increase in serum sodium and you can reduce that by drinking water BEFORE eating a salty meal. Salt and obesity and diabetes: But high salt diets aren’t just about blood pressure… High salt diets are associated with obesity and the development of diabetes. And high salt looks like it works by producing fructose. Salt and kidney disease: People with kidney disease have to be more conscious of reducing salt consumption. However, increased water intake may slow the progression of kidney disease. Can drinking water help keep you skinny? Many animals use fructose to make fat as a means for making water. When you make fat, although there’s no water stored in the fat, when you burn the fat, it makes water. Fructose drives fat production in part to preserve water (not just energy). If you take an animal that’s consuming high fructose, you can suppress some of the obesity and metabolic syndrome by giving it a lot of water. And so the old wives tale that ‘drinking six glasses of water a day is good to help keep you skinny’ is true. It turns out that water suppresses some of the effects of fructose.

title: How excess glucose can cause problems
content: What advice does Rick have to “healthy” people? 1 | Reduce fructose. If we could reduce our fructose intake, it would have a HUGE effect. Unfortunately, this is easier said than done b/c sugar and high fructose corn syrup are in almost everything (especially processed foods). 2 | Secondly, be careful with other things that are used to MAKE fructose. We can make fructose from a high salt diet. We can make fructose if we get dehydrated. High uric acid stimulates fructose production. And in all these situations, we’re MAKING fructose from glucose. The glucose-to-fructose conversion. If you give high amounts of glucose to an animal… as the glucose hits the liver it induces an enzyme called aldose reductase which converts glucose to fructose. Rick’s experiment showed that when feeding mice high glucose it can convert to fructose endogenously. Does this suggest that you get fatty liver from excess glucose even if it’s not high in sugar? Yeah, absolutely, if you have that enzyme induced.

title: Nutrition and metabolic syndrome
content: Normally, you could reverse the induction of this aldose reductase enzyme within a few weeks by restricting sugar…but once your uric acid goes up that will keep it elevated (regardless of sugar intake). Another reason potentially to use allopurinol in addition to fructose restriction to keep uric acid low and mitigate the induction of aldose reductase. A high starch diet becomes a much bigger problem AFTER you get metabolic syndrome. Because once you have metabolic syndrome…Let’s say you stop eating sugar but you continue to eat carbs. The carbs are going to continue to activate through the same pathway. This is why a low carb diet is really great for metabolically ill people.

title: Artificial sweeteners vs. real sugar
content: We have taste buds that sense sweet. When we eat sugar, the taste buds are activated and it stimulates this dopamine response in the brain that tells us that we like this sugar. If you genetically knock out the sweet taste buds in animals…They still like sugar and they will still eat a lot of it. But they won’t like artificial sugar. In other words, the artificial sugar is driven by the sweet taste but what makes animals like real sugar is through its metabolism. So even though but artificial and real sugar have the sweet taste and the dopamine response, the real sugar gives us some pleasure in the periphery where the metabolism takes place. Animals will tend to eat a little bit less sugar when their taste buds are gone, but they still eat enough to develop metabolic syndrome.

title: Studies on artificial sweeteners
content: Peter says aspartame has been studied more by the FDA than any other molecule ingested by humans. So the idea that we “just don’t know” the full safety profile of these things is a little silly to say. There are some studies suggesting risks such as…Like Saccharin, for example, has been associated with little bladder tumors in mice. Aspartame can generate tiny concentrations of formaldehyde.

title: Basic Tastes and Weight Gain
content: Sweet and salty tastes are the most associated with weight gain. For a lab animal to gain weight, it takes 2 months with sugar and 4 months with salt (slower conversion to fructose). And then it takes progressively longer in this order: Umami, Bitter, Sour.

title: Umami and Obesity
content: Some link of umami with obesity in epidemiologic studies. Some situations where you can induce obesity with umami (especially in liquid form). Peter’s take: He thinks the idea that umami (or MSG) is harmful is largely unfounded in the literature.

title: High Glycemic Foods to Reduce
content: Ranking some contributing factors to metabolic disease: 1) Number one is sugar (everything else is less). 2) High glycemic carbs can be converted to sugar. The big four high glycemic food to reduce: 1) Bread 2) Potatoes 3) Chips 4) Rice.

title: Beer and Umami
content: What makes beer so much more dangerous than other alcohols for inducing obesity is because beer has a ton of brewers’ yeast which basically is activating the umami pathways (which is one of the reasons we like beers). People who drink a lot of beer don’t just get abdominal obesity… they get fatty liver, they get high blood pressure, their triglycerides go up. They basically have metabolic syndrome.

title: Fructose Consumption
content: Personally, I would not drink any liquids that have sugar in it or fructose or high fructose corn syrup. He draws a hard line at liquid sugar.

title: Low Fructose Fruits
content: Kiwi and lime and lemon have almost no fructose. Blueberries, raspberries, strawberries are very good. Grapes have a lot of sugar. What I would recommend is to try to not eat too many fruit at one time. If you eat a huge amount of fruit and get all that fructose it will start to overwhelm the good things in fruit. Good things like vitamin C, epicatechin, flavonols, and potassium and all these things that help fight the effects of fructose. For patients that have a non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, we tend to restrict them to 10 grams a day of fructose, only in the form of whole fruit. This means no grapes, no bananas, no large apples, etc.

title: Managing Sugar Intake for Kids
content: Rick lets his kids have birthday cake but tries to sub out some sugar for splenda when they make a cake at home. Absolutely no fruit juice or regular soft drinks, but they can have a diet soft drink now and then. Rick says he wants to make sure they understand WHY, rather than just be an authoritarian. What we try to do is not to be so restrictive that it’s disruptive but we try to be encouraging them to understand that sugar is playing a big role in obesity and diabetes and that it’s unhealthy to eat a lot. Rick is involved with the Living Closer Foundation which tries to teach children how to look at labels on foods to understand the amount of sugar. One experiment they do with kids is to demonstrate that if you put the same sugar in a coke into a cup of tea, it is nearly unpalatable to drink. But the carbonation in soda masks this to some degree.

title: Dried Fruit
content: Dried fruit is the fructose of fruits without the good things in it. It’s like pure fructose.
